title: 115_hr695
content: The "Child Protection Improvements Act of 2017" is the short title of this Act. It establishes a National Criminal History Background Check and Criminal History Review Program. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to establish a program for qualified entities to access national criminal history background checks on covered individuals. Qualified entities can request these checks through designated entities. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow qualified entities to request national criminal history background checks on covered individuals. Requests must comply with guidelines and procedures set by the Attorney General or the State. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow covered individuals to challenge the accuracy of information in national criminal history background checks conducted according to established procedures. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow covered individuals to challenge the accuracy and completeness of information in their criminal history record by contacting the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Designated entities are also included in the process. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to limit fees for background checks conducted by authorized State agencies and the FBI. Fees for national criminal history background checks are also regulated. The designated entity must collect fees at a level that covers the costs of providing services, including remitting a portion to the Attorney General for criminal history background checks. The fee system should not deter volunteers from participating in programs for children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities. The designated entity forwards requests for national criminal history background checks to the Attorney General, who completes fingerprint-based checks and provides the information to the entity. Upon request, the entity may also check a State criminal history database. The Attorney General designates entities to conduct criminal history reviews using specific criteria established by rule. The Attorney General establishes criteria for designated entities to determine fitness based on specific criteria from the Prosecutorial Remedies Act. The term "provider" is replaced with "covered individual" in the text. The term "covered individual" is defined as someone who has, seeks, or may have access to children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities served by a qualified entity, and who is employed by, volunteers with, seeks to be employed by, or owns or operates a qualified entity. The term "designated entity" is defined as an entity designated by the Attorney General based on specific criteria from the Prosecutorial Remedies Act. The term "designated entity" refers to an entity designated by the Attorney General under specific criteria from the Prosecutorial Remedies Act. The Act and its amendments must be fully implemented within 1 year of enactment.
